t: Job 29
Job’s Final Defense
Job*p continued his discourse:
“How*pn I long for the months gone by, for*ld the days when God watched over me,
when*ln his lamp shone on my head and*ld by his light I walked through darkness!
Oh,*ln for the days when I was in my prime, when*ld God’s intimate friendship blessed my house,
when*ln the Almighty was still with me and*ld my children were around me,
when*ln my path was drenched with cream and*ld the rock poured out for me streams of olive oil.
“When*pn I went to the gate of the city and*ld took my seat in the public square,
the*ln young men saw me and stepped aside and*ld the old men rose to their feet;
the*ln chief men refrained from speaking and*ld covered their mouths with their hands;
the*ln voices of the nobles were hushed, and*ld their tongues stuck to the roof of their mouths.
Whoever*ln heard me spoke well of me, and*ld those who saw me commended me,
because*ln I rescued the poor who cried for help, and*ld the fatherless who had none to assist them.
The*ln one who was dying blessed me; I*ld made the widow’s heart sing.
I*ln put on righteousness as my clothing; justice*ld was my robe and my turban.
I*ln was eyes to the blind and*ld feet to the lame.
I*ln was a father to the needy; I*ld took up the case of the stranger.
I*ln broke the fangs of the wicked and*ld snatched the victims from their teeth.
“I*pn thought, ‘I will die in my own house, my*ld days as numerous as the grains of sand.
My*ln roots will reach to the water, and*ld the dew will lie all night on my branches.
My*ln glory will not fade; the*ld bow will be ever new in my hand.’
“People*pn listened to me expectantly, waiting*ld in silence for my counsel.
After*ln I had spoken, they spoke no more; my*ld words fell gently on their ears.
They*ln waited for me as for showers and*ld drank in my words as the spring rain.
When*ln I smiled at them, they scarcely believed it; the*ld light of my face was precious to them.
I*ln chose the way for them and sat as their chief; I*ld dwelt as a king among his troops; I*ld was like one who comforts mourners.
